summary: The "international division of labour" refers to the systematic allocation of production tasks across different countries, optimizing efficiency and resource utilization in global trade. In the context of EU legal and regulatory frameworks, this concept underpins trade agreements and policies that facilitate cross-border economic cooperation. The EU promotes an equitable international division of labour to enhance competitiveness and foster sustainable development. By harmonizing standards and regulations, the EU aims to ensure that member states can effectively engage in global markets while adhering to principles of fair trade and social responsibility. This concept is vital for understanding the dynamics of international trade relations within the EU.
